DIZSKKnTbI_6T99PuFjfsQ.text: I have lived on the same street as E.Pellicci for god knows for how long and nor realizing what a little gem I have next door. For me the place always just looked like..old and brown? Tiny windows, tiny cafe. But once again I learned that I should not judge anything by its looks.Inside the cafe/restaurant is very loud, and friendly. Always busy. It saved my morning after with a simple but big and nourishing breakfast. Definitely a feel good place with a family atmosphere. I have found myself a new local!

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom

1PVBaG_3TxW9aiU2WrLsVg.text: I love the atmosphere in here, and you can get a plate of food that fills you up and clogs your arteries for under a fiver! The pasta dishes are really good too. The spinach and ricotta cannelloni is especially good. What I love about Pellici is that it has a great vibe in there and is fabulous for people watching. You will find yourself squashed in with every Eastend stereotype imaginable. Expect to be called Duchess and do prepared to be squashed. It is cramped and if you go at a peak time you will find yourself squished a bit, but this is part of the charm here. If ever you want to go to a proper Eastend greasy spoon, look no further than Pellici's!

Bmm687laTPczHN-t0djX1g.text: Another classic east end place -- the interior is actually been written up so many times and is condsidered a landmark .Beautiful wood insets and walls the place is hot and really gets full -- with its tiny little reception and cooking area you often find yourself eating at a shared table. Adorable outside with its flower boxes and little house above -- rumour has it the Kray brothers rented this floor at some point in their scary career.Italien family run this place closes during the italien holidays.The food is a real mix - italien meets british meets diner.A real experience to eat here and a must see if you want to sample old world east end

IZOmgAdYctMsJ5OTiDpnNw.text: Wow!  Pretty amazing.  Turns out I'm a sucker for the old times.  And this is so old and so classic.  Just the most perfect cafe interior, all chrome and pleasantly varnished wood.  Real coffee, really good food.It's amazing that they can actually fit all these people in, it's pretty dinky!  But just the best remedy on a weekend for a big night, the night before.  So, they'll do all the variations of cooked breakfast that you could want, a lot of meat.  Grills.  Big choice of steaks.  Chicken.  Pork.  And things like pasta - it is an Italian establishment dontcha know?!!?!??  Probably one of the classic East End cafs.  Really need to go here peeps!

l0TDvOiAazllR_BCmROc9Q.text: Opened since 1900 this is a place to go for breakfast and lunch if you like popular atmosphere plenty of stories. The staff is a whole Italian family who is welcoming at anytime. Behind the counter , you can see the preparation of your toast or sandwich with delicious fresh components :vegetables, cheeses, butter and a tender ciabatta. You can also smell a waking-up flavour of coffee in the morning and during lunch.It's a really small place and generaly you have to share your table with others and at peak time you need to be prepared to wait 10 or 15 minutes.You can hear the Mother from the kitchen , people will treat you very kindly and if you'll meet Nevio , one of the waiters , be prepared to laugh as he is the type of person you like to have around you.Their breakfast is famous as you can mix from a basic english breakfast any other component from an important list.Most of all it's a museum too as there are a lot of pictures around the room with famous TV's stars from the 80's and the 90's who came in.

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom

ahFszah1sKfpVjSHoFv82w.text: An east end institution to be visited! Bread pudding is a must!

ATduKJ4HMq8hVv90zaeuUg.text: This is a small establishment but good. The seating is cramped and the food is good, the owners are very friendly and accomidating towards your wants. It can get very crowded and noisy here. This place is classic and just plain good.

K4ialki4zhv6az3vfFYbCw.text: Perfect old London interior, lots of decorative wood, tables crammed into a tiny space with people crammed around them. Still run by an East End Italian family, fine when the guy tells you all about 'Mum's minestrone' you know it's a bit fake, put on cos people lap up that kind of 'authenticity' but when he remembers you after only your first visit it is genuine and when he manages to find space for all 7 of us from work, even though it's packed and tiny, it really brings home the idea of good service. Aside from the cheeky chappy banter, which is certainly half the experience, the food is really tasty, a mix of old English caff stodge and Italian comfort food and it's pretty cheap. All meals are massive and almost all cost between 5 and 6 pounds. The lasagne is a huge bowl of cheesy deliciousness while pie and mash is drowning in gravy and broccoli cheese. The fry-ups are also enormous and cooked to perfection and they have a proper coffee machine.

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom

6SBS_sF8f2teJRhJmII3Hw.text: Pellicci's, on Bethnal Green Road, is the best cafe in London, if not the entire world. Since 1900, the Pellicci family, many of whom were born in the room upstairs, have been running this tiny art-deco cafe for locals, taxi drivers, showbiz types, and the rest of us. The breakfasts are without peer in their authenticity. It's like going home for a fry-up, with cockney-Italian banter thrown in. You can imagine Michael Caine walking in at any moment. It's tiny, but they always find room for you. You won't need lunch after breakfasting there, and you will always come back.

FCkdENlCMGPQqAGxlzhv-A.text: E.Pellicci is the best place I've ever been to the morning after a big night out. It's not often you have to queue for a table at a greasy spoon but it's well worth the wait, even if it's so tightly packed you could almost pass the ketchup to everyone else in the place. With over a hundred years of history and being run by the same family, it's a unique combination of 50s Italian deco and several generations of Italo-Cockney staff - who make really make the place what it is by making you feel so welcome.This is no fine cuisine, but what they do serve - English breakfasts (& homemade chips), sandwiches and roast dinners - they do very well, especially the former. They have an illustrious list of former clients, most famously the Kray twins and I can also reliably inform that Dave Gorman is one of their many regulars - once you visit it's easy to become one (although it's not advised if you have heart problems). The impressive wood panelled interior is now grade 2 listed, unchanged since the 50s it's remarkably well preserved - but is just one of countless reasons you really have to visit Pellicci's.

dlqR5IydH7ydp1cs_82rhg.text: (eye-talian) family run caff since 1902, so small you wouldn't believe; signora Pellcci Senior is still the chef in command; son Nevio and a team of slim british italian (relatives?) run the deck. Food is the usual mix of caff foods from english breakfast to sunday roast with the italian spaghetti and lasagne.Generous portions, tiny prices, friendly service (couldn't be any friendlier), tiny room.When a patron asked Nevio why they don't buy the shop next door and knock down the wall, Nevio replied something about the fact that money isn't everything.This place has the buzz of those italian pasticcerie in Hoboken New Jersey.If you are in London don't miss this place and don't miss the vibrant multi ethnic alternative area, millions of miles away from touristic london.

Ir4cXSGRB86K92aRVYWOuQ.text: great food great staff not cheap but food for a laugh. the staff keep an eye out for traffic wardens. service is fast its an old placem one of the fer survivors of the east london clean up.easy goin and not for the shy.

GDWyEnqqaECTfdwtiPYMUQ.text: i really like this place. proper cafe with great food, best of all though are the staff who are really talkative and friendly and remember you making you feel very welcome.

ByelJGFY2NeMEb8iOzemsA.text: The BEST cafe I know with 1000s of regulars. Go late or early for lunch to get a table. Traditional fry-ups, delicious sandwiches (ham on the bone etc) and great lasagne, all served with considerable style in this tiny and beautiful establishment with listed status. Also, AFFORDABLE!

ciGOyaZzevRj77ntncpPXg.text: Consistently delicious. I am an ex-pat NYer and was desperate for a decent simple Italian meal, and have finally found it! I wholeheartedly repeat the sentiments of reviews below by saying the interior is gorgeous, the staff friendly from your first visit, and the food always very good with generously sized portions (and reasonable prices). Dining here is a sure fire way to brighten your day and fill your belly.

uu7B5Qi7Ycqvg3Bob-ZvDg.text: This place has good service, however, I thought the veggie sausage that I got was kind of bland. The bubble was good, though. You can't do eggs wrong, and the price was good! You can get a breakfast set for less than 5  pounds!I wish there was more breakfast selection though. Cozy and nice lil joint.

WfOKw9Qg_L-dt9GFVxlzNw.text: This has to be hands down the most heart warming, belly rumbling food in London. The ever changing menu is an array of Italian home cooked feasts that come out piping hot.Now don't expect glamour from this, or someone smartly dressed leading you to your table. He'll have a white apron on but it will have traces of the days special wiped all over it. This place has a honest charm about it and when Leon C took me hear I knew that we would be buddies. It's right up my ally! You'll find the local contractors chow down with the hipsters, sharing a bottle of "red sauce".A great cheap date spot or lunchtime warmer during the winter month, a must for a proper family restaurant experience.

vcoytVHeRzWrrFVjLeISrg.text: Seriously, great food, great service and what a friendly group of servers and staff! Friday and Saturday nights the place is rocking and filled with regulars. This is literally the place where everybody knows your name.

NoGsdTG6Xg-HLrVqMkJ0ZA.text: what amarvel to behold modern civilisation is to be found sprouting out of the e pellici dream boat

WKg2TQ0VvilZypwDShWunw.text: A small but very hospitable place. From the moment you walk in you are threated with smile and you feel like you are home. Went there last week with a friend of mine for a pizza and I swear that was the best pizza I've ever had in my entire life. You should absolutely check it out.

kiP3z7uC5_Aqtq7CLBnFFg.text: If I had an Italian grandmother this is exactly what I would expect her to make. Just as some of the other review say this is a total hole in the wall, no frills establishment that been in the hood for ages. The other diners were very accommodating with a little game of musical chairs so that all the groups were taken care of. The food was homey, hearty and authentic. The best thing that we got was the lasagna, so freaking good. And I don't know if they just liked us or if everyone gets garlic bread but that was a nice touch too. There's just something about the restaurant where you can feel the warmth of being in someone's home versus being in an Olive Garden, god forbid.  The fun for us really started after the meal. I quietly went to the counter to pay while K and J were gabbing about whatever they were talking about. So I pay our tab 22 pound for the 3 of us, great deal. And after hearing the American accent, Nevio (current owner) asked me if it was my first time in East London, much to his surprise I told him it was my first time to London period which really got his attention. I think he was little confused as to how an American would come across his East London establishment. (Thanks Yelp!)So we chatted a little and what would you know, he said you have to take some of my Mom's bread pudding with you, she just made it this morning and you can share it with the girls, so of course I took him up on his offer. K was a little disappointed as she's been there several times and has never been given mom's bread pudding. See it pays to make some friendly conversation. So then he came over to flirt with the girls, telling K that maybe if she flirted a little more or smiled that she would have been given some bread pudding on her previous trips to E Pellicci. Then to top it all off we got some photos with Nevio and he was pretty stoked to show us his auto-graphic book with the celebs that have been though Pellicci. We recognized a lot of them, but we weren't familiar with some of the Brits, of course our highlight was that Ross from Friends had been in there. Talk about a fun experience all around.

arO4Re_8OCd_cATKtvflNA.text: Walking into this tiny establishment, I was instantly greeted by a woman barking orders toward the kitchen, an old man at the door kissing goodbye whom I could only assume were regulars, an array of people crammed shoulder to shoulder piling pies into their mouths, and some of the best smelling food I had been privy to since moving to London.Before I even sat down, I was already in love.Sure, I soon found out all the tidbits about history and tradition and original lasagna recipes and yada yada yada, but I was already so deeply immersed in the menu of proper British fry ups and classic Italian favourites that I didn't even blink at their mention. I just ordered, crammed in shoulder to shoulder with the other patrons, and shoveled pie into my mouth.And wouldn't you know it, I got a kiss on the way out!

JYef0XbvnEC2-Webs9PS_A.text: I found a great pizza experience in this restaurant. both the food and the service was marvelous.

TqA4L_BSOqEnPx4fp9YGwA.text: Perfect for a good value fry up. It's quite busy as it is very popular - we had to wait 15 mins to get a seat inside, but that was at 11am - but it's busy for good reason. It's a great local caff, the people who run it are friendly, you can make your own breakfast out of all the various items, and for London it's a great price for the quality. We were very happy and will definitely return (it will become my local for sure!)

oH1ovqndut75-kAaWpCDkg.text: This bustling East London joint is legendary as a traditional English caff. Old fashioned wood tables feel almost Bavarian in style, and you might end up sharing yours with others. You'll probably hear those 'others' ordering plain white toast with butter (or is it margarine?) and English teas, an occurrence still incomprehensible to my Americanness (why order cheap white toast when you're out to breakfast?). E Pellici's is an informal place, a noisy place, and a reliable place for proper English breakfast food. I had beans, eggs and chips, and it was fine, nice even. It's not fabulous and not meant to be. The caff serves English pies, pasta, and other non-breakfasty items for lunch, which I haven't had so can't vouch for; but as the name implies Italian ownership, one might expect these dishes are also fine, not fabulous, and without question satiating.Service was quick and friendly, not gushy, on my visit, as it should never be in a real caff. The menu is extensive with every variation on chips, beans, eggs, back bacon, toast, fried tomatoes and margarine that one can hope for. Prices are reasonable; really, there's no gourmet goose fat fried chips and no pretention. Overall, I would go back: it's marked as my hotspot for baptising non-British visitors into the fine world of English breakfasts.

a-V1BFxRyC9QHHZKYxcZmA.text: This is a really nice restaurant. The atmosphere is pleasant and you can spend some pleasant time with your friends there. The prices are reasonable, the services are not so fast, but overall  a really good place with delicious pizza.

-MTgbCk0D_Qt93LLzjAbyg.text: Delicious food (breakfast is terrific), fantastic service in a place that makes you feel like you walked into a movie. Must visit if you're in this neighbourhood.

m3n8GM9YGTvY_s2O9YaZAw.text: A great place to go for a fry-up. Full of character, it's a proper East End institution and definitely worth a visit. Nice big mugs of tea too :)

194GMBy77SIZorr17djY1Q.text: I really like the pizza here. The taste is different from the other pizzas I have eaten and I like it very much.

d9WcEFLXWf-dLcbMbhP5FQ.text: I went there last week. The whole place was shut up as they are on holiday until the end of August. I was so dissappointed! I'll be back asap....early Sept! This place is famous with loads of history (including the Krays). Its iconic! . Will right a proper review after. Get there before it dissappears. HerbieCambridge

FH5xK0J_Ct2I1khZoEnypw.text: E Pellicci is one of the best cafe/restaurants I have ever had the pleasure of eating in. It has been an Italian family run business for over one hundred years and is rightly becoming a living legend.The seating is cramped and you can expect to share your table with others. This though is not a negative. It is something to be relished from our past when we weren't so removed from social community living.The breakfasts are stunning and all the food both Italian and English are very well made.When you arrive the welcome by Nevio Junior the grandson of the founder of E Pellicci is so warm and genuine you feel like family. The banter is high and everyone seems to join in. It is so jovial you may not want to leave.The place is so famous, don't be surprised if you find yourself rubbing shoulders with A-list celebrities when you are ordering your Shepherds Pie.

qvKmIZp-v6hPxNKTZwytUw.text: I used to live on the same street as the Pelicci folks, and I ate there at least once or twice a week.This is my favourite breakfast place of anywhere in the entire world. I especially miss the veggie pie with roast potatoes, and broccoli. I could die.

dUXD27bHxJAuzcxLfKvKpQ.text: Unlike some other places, you can "design your own" breakfast at E. Pellicci.  And even better, when I asked the proprietor how many meats I could get as of the breakfast, he said "as many you'd like."  That's the right answer!A good cup of coffee, fried egg, bacon, sausage, mushrooms, black pudding, grilled tomato, fried bread with a healthy dose of friendly banter with the regulars.  What else do you really need to get your day off to the right start?  After breakfast there, I'm good to go for the rest of the day.

u8xiB3XiARYVm8GOJYiQwg.text: Best greasy spoon out there! Friendly and fun, you will inevitably end up talking to someone interesting.

t0ntyAeG1Xs5Sfwgzh-DbA.text: This place is way off the beaten path.  It's located in west London in what appears to be a quiet and cultured neighborhood.  I took the 8 to get there (from Wormwood) and got there shortly after 9am.  For me, it was a little hard to find because they had the roof down (light drizzle) and a farm vendor was setup right in front (the bus stop is RIGHT across the street).Once i found it, I walked in to find only locals...I figured this since they all turned to look at the Yank that appeared without a jacket on and full backpack (plus, I had the "American" accent).  I decided to "stop" at a table outside and proceeded to order the Full English and tea with milk.  It was classic, grilled stem mushrooms, grilled tomato halves, sausage, bacon (which isn't cooked to a crisp like us American's like) and a thick slice of toast with an egg over easy.  You will walk away full and content, it will keep you going for hours as you walk around the British Museum (which is what I did...).  Simple meal with simple flavors, add pepper if desired.For 10 quid, you can't go wrong.  You get to experience the 'burbs of West London and chat it up with the locals (I met 3 locals in a boxing club, to which they invited me!).  A must go if visiting London!

BdzZgDKVWEGqE0tQKWXB6g.text: Crowded and loud and thoroughly fun. The breakfast was excellent and so was the unexpected fun of sitting with strangers in the crush.

BlS-13Lc-xjvU3lSkk0r0w.text: Wonderful place for an English breakfast.  Was here last summer and had the best time.  The owners are very welcoming and can really strike up a conversation with anybody and the food was just great. A little walk from the tubes but we'll worth the trip.

dPMt5X6SaPovwJvYnqVJUw.text: From the moment you walk into the small cafe and here a mix of East London English and Italian being seamlessly interwoven; you know you are in for something memorable.  If you love great affordable food with a warm and charming atmosphere; you must eat here!The food was fantastic. After decades of cooking day in day out one would hope that to be the case.  Luckily for us, they have a burning passion here for making delicious food and happy customers that is palpable.  You will walk away with a huge grin and a full stomach, guaranteed!Family owned and operated, and what a dynamic and lovely family they are.Anna, one of the daughters, sat me down got me a spot of tea, and helped me to decide on the classic English breakfast.  Which is a sausage two slices of ham, a tomato and an egg on top of a piece of fried bread.  It was love at first bite.  I ate everything and was supremely satisfied.  The only sad part was that I had no room left for one final Doner Kebab before catching my flight at Heathrow! This was however a very fitting final meal in London.Not so normally reserved, I sat and took in all the sounds and smells.  The conversations between the staff and the regulars.  One of those great small moments when you feel like you've wandered into a film and are just a member of the audience.  Of course, non-participation isn't an option in a cafe which could seat maybe 25 people with 4 very active and friendly staff.  I looked on while Anna shouted orders in italian between kitchen and staff; then chatted with her customers in her lovely East London accent.  Nev, the son came out from the kitchen to have a bit of fun and chat with the customers that had come in.   One such table were a group of Medi-Helicopter crew wearing bright orange emergency gear.  Two local brits and two observers one Kiwi and one from Texas.  Brit:"I want you to meet my boys here they're from, New zealand and this one He's from Dallas.  Have you ever been to Dallas?"Nev:"No, Thank God!" (everyone laughs) "But I did very much enjoy watching it on the Tele growing up!"  Ah, british humor...Anna:"So you are here as observers, are you?" They nod.  Well, let me tell you how it works.  You've just finished up your breakfasts and so any second now; just as it's time for the bill to come there'll be an emergency call coming in and you'll all have to leave unexpectedly!" (laughs around) Her tone went from joking to sincere, "Seriously though, Thank you for what you all are doing.  It's a great service that you do for everyone!"....Seated at Another table were two female students from China. Nev greeted them with his best "Nin hao!" and then proceeded to ask them if they'd like to meet his Mum.  Mom of course works in the kitchen and was more than happy to stop what she was doing and say hello to the girls.  After that he began to try to convey some of the areas gangster history through broken English and hand gestures.  One theme of the morning chatter was that of the Kray brothers whom are portrayed in the new movie "Legend" by Tom Hardy.  According to Nev they used to come here for breakfast very regularly; and I can see why.Anna, greeted each and every customer as they arrived and as they left.  Thanking them for their patronage, and encouraging them to return with a genuine love and appreciation.  Something that was not as common as I had expected in other places I came to in London.Recognizing that I was a tourist; she offered me some free chips on the side which were fantastic.  Who is going to say no to free chips???We had a lovely chat about the U.S. and her last holiday to Florida with the family.  As I was readying to leave, paying the bill and such(which was a ridiculously cheap 6 pound and change) She insisted on giving me a slice of freshly baked bread pudding straight out of the oven by Momma herself.  I declared that I was stuffed and would pop if I took it, but she insisted and I ate it later before getting on my plane.  What a dear.  This place is a gem, not to be missed while you're in London!Cheers Anna and Nev!  Thanks for the memories.-Mr. Doug

0l-ulMfYXnYEQ_MubGCrJA.text: One of the top 3 breakfasts in the world!: would put it #2 on my list, behind Bryant's in Memphis, Tennessee and just ahead of The Omelet House in Las Vegas. Way better than average "full" breakfast. Why? Mainly because they know how to cook tomatoes. I know it sounds silly, but they get so much flavor out of them than anywhere else. Black pudding also better-than-average.Also, I really like places that like to say "Yes." This place will basically say yes to any order if they've got the ingredients. Why aren't more places like this?While the breakfast tea is, again, way better-than-average, they also know how to make a proper espresso. No visit to London is complete without a visit here.

gBFkME0p8l3axAZYjZesyQ.text: Terrible breakfast - cheap ingredients badly cooked. Pale eggs. Soggy white toast. Mushrooms swimming in grease. I stand by this. Regardless. The mushrooms were swimming in oil. The black pudding was dry and cold. The eggs were pale pale yellow. I didn't eat a sausage so can't comment.

lXH_UN4m9feGer3ccnw0Fg.text: As a foreigner looking for a full English breakfast, I was a little worried that this small eatery with clearly devoted patrons might give four Americans a bit of a hard time when we showed up late on a Wendesday morning.  We were in desperate need to a high caloric meal and stiff tea to deal with our lingering jet lag and were willing to suffer any gruff Englishman to get it.We were surprised.  First, the staff was amazing.  Truly some of the friendliest people we met on our trip.  Second, the food.  I've had my share of full fry breakfasts, and so I was really looking forward to the meal, but I wasn't expecting so many options. Each of us loved our meal, and had we been staying closer we would have probably come back.  Third, the price.  Even with the conversion rate this meal was a deal.  And the waiter even brought out a plate of chips so we could try them since his mum hand cuts them.  ::SWOON::I wasn't sure if I should Yelp this place because it instantly made my "Great Secret Places" list, and I never want it to change.  But since I live so far away, I hope you keep it in business so I can visit it when I return.

oiJI6FXV2e9hBEI7FQiiFA.text: This place has been called a gem by almost every reviewer now, but it's for real! Family run, with the owner managing, bussing, chatting, taking orders and doing it all in the dining room like it's his own house. Always had the warmest welcome here - the first time, we were given complimentary bread pudding made by his mom to go, and the second time he was showing us photos of his baby daughter on his phone. Food is fresh, home cooked and fantastic, all in a throwback atmosphere. Funny mix of older regulars, young locals and, increasingly, tourists.

fdHjemKQ5JcfHzAfpEHKGQ.text: Friendly neighborhood cafe. Classic English breakfast and Italian fare straight from Tuscany. Friendly staff with a free local history lesson on the urban renewal of Bethnal Green. The staff know everybody,  making this feel like a local.

i-bbRppl5Qn6-tYq87fdjA.text: Our favourite restaurant in London - every trip here feels like coming home to family! Cant recommend their sandwiches and breakfast enough, and all very affordable! Full of loads of history and they do everything they can to make sure you feel right at home. Love it!

cwsqGIwhZN3QSwUvzkkQMA.text: One of my favorite places I visited on my last trip to London. Nevio was our server and he was incredibly friendly and definitely left a lasting impression on me. Saw this listed in Serious Eats best place for an English breakfast and it was one of the best I've had. Food, service, and experience were perfect! Would definitely recommend it to anyone in the area but I wouldn't come with too large a group since the place is a bit small.

DZH_yC4MIKVLgHlNDb7ixg.text: Great spot. Very friendly, engaging service. Good and hearty food served in generous portions. Good value. The place can get pretty busy - it's relatively small - so don't be surprised if you show up and need to wait. Overall this place is a real gem, and absolutely worth seeking out.

-JPeC3G_mBJOaAdxnGSeEQ.text: What would happen if Italian immigrants came into East London at the turn of the century?They'd open E Pellicci. Which they did. Which is why you should go.It's the most Italian, and yet the most London eating experience you'll ever have. Chicken Rustica with gravy and roast spuds? check. Liver, veg & chips? Yes, that too. Sandwiches? They'll basically make you a sandwich out of anything they have. All good. Reasonably priced (you'll get a massive meal with a drink - like fresh squeezed orange juice for under a tenner. Tea is 60p. And it's good.Then there's the decor. It's lovely. Art nouveau. Original. Preserved. Probably 'cos they never had the cash to transform it in the 50s and 60s when wood grain and coloured glass became passé. And that's good, too. There's no glamour. Just incredibly nice people who will treat you like a regular the first time you come in - one of the workers finishing off her shift went round and said goodbye (mostly by name) to every single person in the place.It's teeny, tiny, and absolutely worth a visit. One of London's great eateries, reasonably priced, and full of lovely, filling, warm, friendly food and conversation.

KnsmFDgbSTDtLa-fOqu2sw.text: Great spot for some breakfast. The choices in the menu aren't that much but what more would you need than a Full English and a cup of coffee to wash it down. I like the interior design as it was somehow crammed without being too much or overwhelming. The staff are warm and friendly, I felt so nice and welcomed and the wonderful food just topped that feeling. The spot is a real find, if you're wondering where to get lunch or have a drink or two.

pI8h52u15FvkMa0wBXbKyA.text: Apparently the greasy spoon of the Kray twins, this is my favourite local cafe. The fry up is second to none, with really good quality sausages and bacon, and you can swap any of the ingredients for anything on their list for no cost at all. The pasta is amazing too, but what makes this place particularly special are the amazing Cockney/Italian family that run the place. They are so friendly, and give the whole place such atmosphere!

IY80rDiFxEkyWKNGtYZGkw.text: Everything was... okay, I guess. Not overwhelmingly impressed but I'm not sure I would have known it was "great" if I wasn't told about it beforehand. Alternatively: it wasn't "cheap" enough to get around it being noisy, etc.

cBxSQGu-_9ay-s5flOEEfA.text: A faded art deco interior, loud, Italian, greasy spoon, churning out English breakfasts to a mix crowd of foodies, locals and arty types. A wonderful amalgamation.Much better chance of a table in the week. Forget about it on Saturdays.

dbsw1AZGRcqpWIoyoqVGrg.text: This place was so much fun! My husband and I went here while on vacation in London in May. We happened to be staying in the Bethnal Green area and had many people recommend it to us for a traditional English breakfast, which is similar to American just with grilled tomatoes, beans, and mushroom. Upon entering it seemed very small and homey, just a few tables and a few staff. They were the nicest people! They were having loud conversations across the restaurant with guests and interacting with everyone- half speaking Italian. It made us feel like we were locals! They showed us a photo album of all the famous people that had been there before, and while leaving, the nice lady packed up some bread pudding and said that her grandmother made it this morning and sent it home with us for free! Overall I really treasured this experience and felt like I was off the beaten path and met some wonderfully friendly people!

vtgd9aeyG26Xch6B2zkIRA.text: E Pellicci is a charming little cafė that has been open for over a century. It was one of the few options on Bethnal Green Road that served more than the standard English breakfast. After searching all over for a lighter breakfast my companion and I decided that E Pellicci was the best option. We were lucky to get a table outside considering it was Saturday and the place was completely packed, which should be expected. It was one of the few places on the road that was always packed with locals whenever I passed it. The man who served us who I believe was part of the family was very kind and helpful. They only accept cash so my companion had to run down to a shop to get money out of an ATM machine. The prices are very reasonable. I had such a delicious ciabatta, fresh mozzarella, tomato and basil sandwich. It was so huge that I could only manage to eat 1/3 of it. It was nice to be able to relax and chat without having any of the staff rush us considering how popular the cafė is. Whenever I'm in London I will definitely stop here!

taMQvZK7nuZtYVz5RMyXQg.text: This place is very special with its original 50s shopfront and grade II listed interior.It is loud, bustling and you can get a huge plateful of home-cooked food for about 6 pounds.It is places like this that make me love London; a real gem.

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. Grade II listed interior
Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom

HBq5bLu3FZfyBR35na2cdw.text: Visited London for 2 days and wanted authentic food, nice small family owned since 1901. Great food, good price and nice hospitality.

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. Custard and apple pie.
Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. Steak and chips.

PKVPG_jkS7BI9uYVuovy1A.text: Hands down, this was the best service I received in my week stay in London. I came here with my sister on a recommendation from a friend and we were not disappointed. The place is tiny, but the owner was all over the place, chatting with everyone and engaging in conversation. You could tell he truly loves what he does. Breakfast was delicious also, and the pasta dishes people ordered who sat a few tables over looked really good too. I wish I lived here so I could return often!

Rj9WHrC_na7PalmFBa3q5g.text: Really impressed with this family run homestyle restaurant. It is almost insulting when people refer to this place as a greasy spoon. It is a local restaurant with lots of regulars and visitors like us. Best of all, they treat visitors as if they're regulars. As afar as the breakfast menu goes, it can please everyone. From those who want a proper English breakfast to those like me who aren't as interested in breakfast and had cannelloni at 9:30 in the morning. Yes...breakfast and pasta can both be served at 9:30 in the morning. The cream sauce on the cannelloni was wonderful and the full breakfasts were very satisfying. Anthony Bourdain and other travel books were not wrong. Get up early and make the journey on the Central Line one stop east of the City of London to Bethnal Green and enjoy the friendly and caring service. You won't be disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. Family friendly service at this wonderful homestyle restaurant

oxaauoeHl_-A8tFaDWjrsQ.text: Probably the best café/"greasy spoon" in London. Certainly the best English breakfast I've had! Their specials (like the chicken and bacon pie with broccoli and roast potato) are just as amazing. Completely family-run, and you can tell in the atmosphere. Incredibly efficient, too. You won't wait long for food, but expect to queue for a table during the brunch rush (esp. Saturday mornings). Worth every second of waiting. I come here as many times as I can! It's also a great way of chatting and getting to know people, as you'll never know who you'll end up sitting next to. One of the last places in London where you can have a full English and a cuppa for less than a tenner. Bravi!

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom

nvo83rfJgYwu2msQq_4pHg.text: What a great treat! We are so bummed out that we went here on our last day! Definitely a go more than one time restaurant. This morning we had the Full English with one order of hand cut chips, tea with milk. DELICIOUS! The owners were so nice! We stayed and had an extra coffee. While we were enjoying our coffee the homemade bread pudding came out. They gave us a serving! Delicious! Unlike American bread pudding this one is crispy and only slightly sweet. If you are anywhere near here, you need to eat here! We also saw some other tables have their pasta, looked very tasty! Thank you Pellicci family for a lovely morning!

ZNZvoF1Ru9lRNt27mUO4Og.text: Honestly what a great place. It's a tiny hole in the wall in the outskirts of London, and a very very homey place. It seems that lots of locals frequent the establishment -- that's how you know it's good! It does take CASH ONLY, so make sure you bring money! The day we came, they were quite busy and seemed a bit understaffed, so everyone was a bit harried but friendly nonetheless. Everyone is extremely nice and the food is delicious! I ordered the full English breakfast -- because of course I had to -- and it did not disappoint. You can add-on other things as well. They have a pretty extensive menu and it's very inexpensive (I think my platter was less than £6 or £7). It's not fancy -- it's a very no-frills restaurant, but if you're trying to find an authentic London English breakfast experience, look no further!

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. Full English breakfast with added hash browns

lfSxh2PtCfRoMGF7uPitmA.text: I've been back three times now and E Pellici is consistently the best food we've eaten in London and one of the most memorable experiences! Just wanted to update and attach this yummy photo :)

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom

ycJZoRjqr6rUCpauiecO3w.text: After seeing this place on many videos, it was a go to for the full English breakfast experience. The food was good but what set the place apart was the welcoming staff/family. They interacted with our kids through the meal and made us feel as if welcomed. Tight quarters so expect to cozy up to your fellow patrons.

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom
Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom
Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom

754Dw6JxJTquvz_GhSI1Uw.text: What a wonderful restaurant.  The service was great and the food was delicious.  I wish there were more locations, but that would ruin the charm.

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. Breakfast (build your own)

Eukqkt_huMKhYU-Ujdh6yg.text: My first breakfast in London and boy did it not disappoint. This place was FANTASTIC. Oh my god what a diamond in the rough. Small cozy smells like mmmmmmmmmm Delish !!!!!  Fresh baked pastries, bread and coffee aromas fill the air. The owner and his family are there to greet you the second you step inside. Ask to see their photo album, the list of celebrities who have eaten there are quite cool. Coffee was perfect, breakfast was spot on and their homemade special recipe bread pudding is TO DIE FOR!!!!  you'll kick yourself for weeks if you leave without trying it. Enjoy

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. Full English breakfast
Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. American style pancakes

FSvMGYTaRQ1uroaYe05BjA.text: Every time when I visit a restaurant or café, I always judge it by their services first. I don't care whether the place is a fine dining one or just a fast food place. It is essential if you want people to come back. And I reckon this place has done an excellent job. It really made my day when I came here for breakfast. I can totally see why this place is always crowded. Very good and friendly waiters. Very good and fulfilling breakfast as well. The americano is excellent! I definitely recommend it to those of you looking for a good meal with some rich heritage.

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom
Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom
Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom

_ZSLwoTFdX_yq6v0ayDZzQ.text: I'd go as far as to say this is the best cafe in London, really! The service is compare to being welcomed into someone's house and the food is amazing. Would highly recommend!

mIYXnIQ7un-l7ms9ZW5THQ.text: Had a fantastic breakfast at E Pellicci this morning. Good hearty English breaky (with as little or as many trimmings as you'd like), happy and chatty staff, and all at a great price - what more do you want from a greasy spoon? Lots of regulars with a few out of towners sprinkled in, everyone was made to feel welcome. Definitely a must visit if you are in the area (or even if you aren't!)

_gTpje9wEy_kPJYpET5t9A.text: If you are front the states, think of this as a Cheers Style diner.  We walked in upon a few recommendations from the locals.Turns out the Pelllicci family has owned and operated this restaurant for 100+ years.  At 3:00 PM, this place is PACKED.  And I mean filled to the brim, yet somehow the staff there still made us feel welcome and at home.  We were seated with random strangers which was uncomfortable.Since we were in England, we ordered the English Breakfast.  Food wise, it was a classic "diner" feel.  But the service, oh man are those guys awesome.  This is exactly what 100 years of pride and joy amount to...amazing service.Each of the staff stopped over to see how we were doing and chatted with us for a few minutes while we were away.  I immediately felt like they were my new friends.  We were even given complimentary bread pudding made by their mom to go.I never felt more at home and more welcome in a cafe before.  The food is good, above standard but its worth the experience.

8QiQIOqOnakti21vFda2aw.text: Amazing chicken pie! This place has great food but the atmosphere makes the place a local staple. They are so sweet and really make you feel like your part of the family.

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. Chicken and mushroom pie

p0MnbMZASquxpoDeF23hZQ.text: A historic fry up place in the east end that I frequent if I'm hungover or staying around in the area after a heavy night.Proper old skool Italian/English greasy spoon that was visited by the Kray brothers and how it got its name to be famous.A great fry up. Obviously get the full English. Some right characters inside but good honest grub that really has that old London feel even if the city is becoming modernised.

NiKxE_LbTKokxX1CCqaZsw.text: I felt like a regular from day one. Don't be shy....check it out! Breakfast and Italian is excellent.

F0i4VopsKWAZ7_D1SjstsQ.text: Great spot, and one of the best places to eat the full English breakfast and Italian food in London for the last 100 years!This little cafe is situated in one of the most multicultural and gentrified London neighbourhoods. You just have to stop at Bethnal Green underground station and just walk for a mile or so in the main road.The cafe is very, very little and can be quite packed with costumers at lunch hour. I have to say that the staff (they were all part of the same family) was very friendly and engaging. They were able to speak different languages and really entertain the costumers! Even my brother accidentally encountered the grandmother of the owner - who also happens to be the chef of the restaurant - and they even had a little chat together. I will never forget the service!The food was excellent. We all ordered the full breakfast which tasted like no full breakfast I've tasted before. Everything looked fresh and cooked to perfection. The apple crumble and the black coffee were also delicious.At the end of our meal, the waitress gave us a slice of home made cake her grandmother made specially for new costumers. She said we should try their freshly made pastas the next time we eat there. I can't wait to eat there again somewhere in the future.Overall, this is a very authentic and genuine place to eat Italian food in London, and the prices are reasonable. Highly recommended to anyone visiting the city.

photos.caption: Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. Full English breakfast
Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. A cup of black coffee and apple crumble with vanilla ice cream
Photo of E Pellicci - London, United Kingdom. Main entrance

1mLR80qjltFFPNVYDugQvA.text: I wasn't leaving London without a proper English breakfast. As the waiter/cook/son of one of the chefs told us, this place blew up in popularity after Anthony Bourdain mentioned it in his London episode of The Layover (S1E9). However, when Bourdain sits down to eat eggs on fried toast, it's actually at a different place, which is a bit misleading. I can see why though - E Pellicci is a bit on the small side, but not without charm. It's been around since 1900 and it has a hand-carved wood interior. Luckily for us, there's also outdoor seating (about 5 tables). We went with the modestly priced full English breakfast (which included white sausage, bacon, mushrooms, grilled tomatoes, and a fried egg on fried toast) with the addition of black pudding. With a cup of tea, it totaled just 7 GBP. A fine deal. The sausage and the mushrooms were the best parts, but be warned - you definitely need to come hungry because it's a hefty meal. Not for the faint of stomach.The employee who I mentioned earlier (Liv) also struck up a conversation with us about America and NYC, and would not let us leave without a generous sample of his mom's bread pudding. Super nice guy. I wish them continued successes well into the future!

zmk_uFUkvoLhuL4YCrU_yA.text: I call it the Regency Cafe of the East due to its legacy and authentic experience. Went this morning for their Full English..very satisfying meal for just £6.  Tremendous old school charm with a family team running the operations, and are louder than the diners themselves.  I love the art deco touches that I assume have been kept for several decades.  Not a five star because of the rather inconsistent service/friendliness, but I'd be more than happy to return with a friend.
